title: I'm a Fire Lookout in The Mountains. Things Are Very Strange Here.
full_text: I arrived at Fire Watchtower 47 on a Monday morning in late June, my boots crunching on the gravel path that led to the base of the structure. The tower rose above me like a solitary sentinel, 70 feet of weathered wood climbing toward the clear blue sky. A slight breeze rustled through the surrounding pines, carrying the sweet scent of sap and summer warmth. My duffle bag grew heavier with each step as I began climbing the spiral wooden staircase. The steps creaked under my weight, announcing my arrival to anyone who might be waiting at the top. Sweat beaded on my forehead by the time I reached the halfway point, and I paused to catch my breath, looking out at the vast expanse of forest stretching in every direction. Green treetops swayed gently below me, creating a living carpet that seemed to breathe with the wind. "Harris! About time you showed up," a gruff voice called from above. I looked up to see Leo Shepherd leaning over the railing of the observation deck, his ranger hat casting a shadow over his weathered face. I raised my hand in greeting and continued my climb, my legs burning from the exertion. When I finally reached the top landing, Leo stood waiting, arms crossed over his chest. He was a tall man with the kind of leathery skin that came from decades in the outdoors, his salt and pepper hair cropped close to his head. His uniform looked as if it had been pressed that morning despite the remote location. "Welcome to your home for the next two weeks," Leo said, extending a calloused hand that I shook firmly. "Let's get you settled." The cabin at the top of the tower was small but functional, a single room with windows on all sides offering a 360-degree view of the surrounding wilderness. A narrow cot was pushed against one wall, a small kitchenette occupied another, and a desk with radio equipment dominated the center of the space. Leo wasted no time getting to business. "Your job is simple, Harris. You scan for smoke, you monitor weather patterns, and you make radio reports twice daily, 0700 and 1900 hours. Got it?" "Yes, sir," I replied, setting my duffle bag on the floor beside the cot. Leo walked me through the equipment, showing me how to use the radio, the weather instruments, and the high-powered spotting scope mounted on a tripod near the desk. "Forest is dry this year," Leo said, pointing toward the eastern section. "We've already had two small fires in that region. Keep your eyes peeled." He tapped his finger on a laminated map spread across the desk. "Any questions?" I shook my head, taking in the simplicity of my duties. Scan, monitor, report. I could handle that. "Good," Leo said with a nod. "I'll be back in two weeks. Radio if there's an emergency, but otherwise, stick to the schedule." He moved toward the stairs, then turned back. "And Harris, try not to go stir-crazy up here. Happens to some folks their first time." With that parting advice, Leo descended the stairs, leaving me alone in my new temporary home. I listened as his footsteps faded, followed by the sound of an engine starting and then growing distant as he drove away. I spent the rest of that first day unpacking my belongings and familiarizing myself with the equipment. The spotting scope was powerful enough to see miles into the distance, allowing me to scan large sections of forest for any signs of smoke or fire. The radio crackled occasionally with chatter from other rangers and fire crews, but mostly there was silence. My first two days passed uneventfully. I fell into an easy routine of scanning the horizon, checking weather readings, and making my scheduled reports. The solitude didn't bother me. I had always been comfortable with my own company, and the panoramic views made for a constantly changing landscape to observe. Sunrise and sunset were particularly spectacular from my elevated position, painting the sky in colors no artist could fully capture. On the third night, I was sitting at the desk reviewing my notes when I heard it, heavy footsteps in the underbrush below the tower. The sound was unmistakable against the normal nighttime forest ambiance of chirping insects and occasional owl calls. I set down my pen and listened more intently. The footsteps continued, accompanied by the sound of branches snapping and leaves rustling. Someone was definitely down there, and from the erratic pattern, they weren't moving with the confidence of someone who knew where they were going. I grabbed my flashlight from the desk drawer and stepped out onto the observation deck that wrapped around the cabin. The night air was cool against my face as I leaned over the railing, pointing my light toward the source of the noise. The beam cut through the darkness, illuminating the clearing at the base of the tower. A man stumbled into the circle of light, his clothes torn and dirty. He had no backpack, no water bottle, none of the basic gear any hiker would carry. He shielded his eyes from the sudden brightness, looking up toward me. "Hello?" He called, his voice carrying clearly in the still night air. "Is someone up there? I need help." I swept the light across the surrounding area, checking for anyone else, but saw only trees swaying gently in the breeze. "I'm coming down," I called back, keeping my flashlight trained on him as I made my way to the stairs. The descent felt longer than it had that morning, each step taking me closer to the stranger who had appeared from nowhere. As I reached the bottom of the staircase, I kept a cautious distance between us. Up close, I could see he was a man in his mid-30s with disheveled brown hair and wide, anxious eyes that darted around nervously.His jeans were torn at the knees, and his T-shirt had a long rip across the chest. Despite the warm June night, he was shivering. "Thanks for coming down," he said, his voice quavering slightly. "I'm lost. Been walking for hours trying to find my way back to the campground." "I'm Teddy Harris," I said, keeping my flashlight pointed slightly away from his face, but still illuminating him enough to see clearly. "I'm the fire watch operator here." "Jacob," he replied. "Jacob Franklin." He extended his hand, which I shook briefly, noting how cold his fingers felt despite the mild temperature. "Which campground are you trying to find?" I asked, mentally reviewing the map of the area. Jacob ran a hand through his hair, looking over his shoulder into the darkness behind him. "Pine Ridge," he said after a pause that felt too long. "I went for a hike this morning and got turned around." Something about his story didn't add up. Pine Ridge Campground was well marked and only two miles from a main road. Even if he had gotten lost during a day hike, it seemed unlikely he'd end up here, miles from any established trail. "You're pretty far off the beaten path," I said, watching his reaction carefully. "How long have you been out here?" Jacob shifted his weight from one foot to the other, his fingers fidgeting with the torn edge of his shirt. "I'm not sure," he said, glancing over his shoulder again. "It feels like forever. I just want to get back to camp." I noticed how he kept looking behind him, as if expecting someone to emerge from the trees at any moment. His nervous energy was palpable, making me increasingly uneasy. "Did you come alone?" I asked, sweeping my flashlight beam around us once more. "Yes," Jacob answered, too quickly. "I'm alone. Just need directions." I studied him for a moment longer. His clothes weren't just torn. They looked like they'd been through much more than a day hike gone wrong. And there was something in his eyes, a haunted look that made me wonder what he'd seen or experienced out in these woods. "The campground is about four miles that way," I said, pointing east. "Follow the main trail with the yellow markers. It'll take you straight there." Jacob's eyes followed my gesture, and he nodded rapidly. "Yellow markers. Got it. Thank you." He took a step backward, still facing me, his body language suggesting he was eager to leave. The way he kept glancing around made my skin crawl. Whatever had happened to Jacob Franklin out in these woods, I wasn't sure I wanted to know. "Do you need water or anything before you go?" I offered, partly out of genuine concern and partly to see how he'd respond. "No," he said, already backing away toward the tree line. "I'll be fine now. Thanks for your help." I watched as Jacob turned and hurried toward the trees in the direction I'd indicated. His footsteps faded into the darkness, leaving me alone again at the base of the tower with an unsettling feeling in the pit of my stomach. I pointed toward the main trail, my flashlight beam cutting through the darkness to illuminate the yellow markers attached to tree trunks along the path. "Four miles east, following those yellow markers," I said. "You can't miss Pine Ridge Campground if you stick to that trail." Jacob Franklin nodded, his wide eyes reflecting the flashlight beam. His torn shirt fluttered slightly in the night breeze. "Thanks," he mumbled, the word coming out as barely more than a whisper. He backed away from me, never turning his back, those anxious eyes still darting over my shoulder into the surrounding forest. I watched as he finally turned and hurried toward the trees, disappearing into the darkness where my light couldn't reach. His footsteps faded until I could no longer hear them, leaving me standing at the base of Firewatch Tower 47 with an unsettled feeling in my gut. Something wasn't right about Jacob's story. Pine Ridge was a well-marked popular campground, only a couple miles from the main road. How had he gotten so lost? And those clothes, they looked like they'd been through more than just a day hike gone wrong. I climbed back up the spiral staircase to my post, each wooden step creaking under my weight. Inside the cabin, I checked my watch. Just past midnight. I made a note in my log about the encounter, documenting the time and Jacob's description. If he was genuinely lost, I wanted a record of having provided assistance. The isolation of the tower felt more pronounced after human contact. I sat at my desk, the radio equipment silent, the windows on all sides showing nothing but darkness beyond the glass. I picked up my binoculars and did another scan of the horizon, looking for any sign of smoke or fire, though it was difficult to see much at night. 20 minutes later, I heard it. More footsteps. Different ones this time. More measured, deliberate, not the panicked stumbling of Jacob Franklin. I grabbed my flashlight again and moved to the observation deck. Shining the beam down, I caught sight of another figure emerging from the trees. This one moved with purpose, his steps confident despite the darkness. "Hello?" I called down. The beam illuminated a man in a tan jacket. He was solidly built, around six feet tall with closely cropped dark blonde hair. Unlike Jacob, his clothes showed no signs of distress or damage. He looked up at my light with unnervingly calm, gray eyes. "Evening," he called up, his voice controlled and measured. "I seem to have lost my way."I descended the stairs again, keeping my flashlight trained on him. As I reached the bottom, I noticed how still he stood, barely shifting his weight as he waited. "I'm Dylan Romero," he said when I approached. His face was clean-shaven with a prominent jawline. "I'm trying to get back to Pine Ridge Campground. Can you point me in the right direction?" The same destination as Jacob. The coincidence made my skin prickle. "Pine Ridge?" I repeated. "That's the second person tonight looking for that campground." Dylan's expression didn't change. "Is that so?" "Yeah. About 20 minutes ago. Guy named Jacob Franklin." Dylan gave a small nod, but offered no further comment. His lack of surprise or curiosity struck me as odd. "Pine Ridge is four miles east," I said, pointing to the same trail I directed Jacob toward. "Follow the yellow markers on the trees. The trail is pretty straightforward." "Thank you," Dylan said, his words perfectly enunciated. He turned to leave, taking a few steps toward the trail. Then he stopped abruptly. He stood completely still for several seconds as if listening for something I couldn't hear. Without warning or explanation, Dylan spun around and headed in the opposite direction, the same path Jacob had taken earlier. "Hey," I called after him. "That's not the way to Pine Ridge." Dylan kept walking, ignoring me completely. "Sir! Mr. Romero!" I shouted. "You're going the wrong way." He never looked back, never acknowledged me. Within moments, he vanished into the darkness of the forest. I stood there, flashlight beam pointed uselessly at the spot where he disappeared. What the hell was going on? Two lost hikers in one night both asking for directions to the same place, and then the second one deliberately going the wrong way following the path of the first. I climbed back up to the tower, my mind racing with possibilities, none of them comforting. Was Dylan following Jacob? Why? And why pretend to be lost if he knew exactly where he was going? I added this second encounter to my log, noting the time and Dylan's description. I spent the rest of the night on edge, scanning the forest below more frequently than necessary, listening for any unusual sounds. But the forest remained quiet. The next morning, I radioed Leo Shepherd during my scheduled 0700 report. "Tower 47 to base. Over." The radio crackled. "This is base. Go ahead, 47." "Morning weather conditions are clear. Visibility 15 miles. Wind from the southwest at five miles per hour. Temperature 62 degrees. No smoke or fire activity observed." I paused, then added, "I had two unusual visitor incidents last night I wanted to report." "Visitors?" Leo's gruff voice came back. "What kind of visitors?" I explained about Jacob and Dylan, their strange behavior, and how Dylan had followed Jacob's path rather than taking the directions to Pine Ridge. There was a long pause before Leo responded. "Probably just hikers who got turned around. Nothing to worry about." "But the second guy deliberately went the wrong..." "Harris," Leo cut me off. "Part of being on fire watch is dealing with lost hikers. It happens. Maybe they were camping together and got separated. Maybe they were meeting up somewhere else. Not our concern unless they start a fire." "It just seems strange." "Focus on your job, Harris. Keep your eyes on the forest for smoke. That's what we're paying you for. Base out." The radio went silent. I sat back in my chair, frustrated by Leo's dismissive response. Sure, dealing with lost hikers might be routine, but there was nothing routine about what I'd witnessed. The next two days passed without incident. I maintained my schedule, scanning for smoke, checking weather readings, making my radio reports, but I couldn't shake the uneasiness from those strange encounters. I found myself frequently looking in the direction where Jacob and Dylan had disappeared, half expecting to see them emerge from the trees again. On the morning of the third day after the encounters, I was at my desk reviewing weather data when I heard it, the distinctive thump, thump, thump of helicopter rotors. I stepped onto the observation deck, scanning the sky until I spotted it, a dark military-style helicopter approaching from the north. It wasn't unusual to see forest service helicopters, especially during fire season, but this one was different. Larger, painted a matte black instead of the usual green or white of government aircraft. I grabbed my binoculars and tracked its movement. The helicopter flew low over the treetops, following what appeared to be a deliberate course. About half a mile from my tower, it slowed and began to descend into a small clearing. Through my binoculars, I watched it land. The rotors continued to spin as the side door slid open. Three men in dark clothing jumped out, moving with practiced efficiency. They unloaded a large wooden crate from the helicopter's cargo hold, carefully lowering it to the ground. The crate was about the size of a refrigerator made of rough wood with metal reinforcements at the corners. The men positioned it at the edge of the clearing then quickly returned to the helicopter. Within minutes, they were airborne again, the helicopter rising above the trees and banking away to the north, the same direction from which it had come. I kept my binoculars trained on the clearing long after the sound of rotors had faded.The wooden crate sat there, alone and out of place in the wilderness. No markings I could see from this distance, no obvious reason for its delivery to such a remote location. I lowered my binoculars, my mind filled with questions. What was in that crate? Why deliver it to the middle of nowhere? And was there any connection to the strange hikers from three nights ago? The forest had just gotten a lot more interesting and a lot more concerning. After four days in the tower, I decided to investigate the crate the helicopter had delivered. I had reported it to Leo during my morning check-in, but his response had been predictably dismissive. "Just keep an eye on the horizon for smoke, Harris. That's your job." The clearing was about half a mile east of my position. I waited until after my evening report at 7:00, then grabbed my backpack with water, a protein bar, my flashlight, and a small first aid kit. The sun hadn't set yet, but it hung low in the sky, casting long shadows through the trees as I made my way down the spiral staircase. The forest was quiet except for the occasional bird call and the soft crunch of pine needles under my boots. I followed the narrow trail that branched east from the main path, pushing aside low-hanging branches and stepping carefully over exposed roots. My mind kept returning to those two strange hikers from a few nights ago, Jacob with his torn clothes and haunted expression, and Dylan, who had deliberately gone the wrong way despite my warnings. After about 15 minutes of hiking, I reached the edge of the clearing where I'd watched the helicopter land. The space was roughly circular, maybe 70 feet across, with tall grass flattened in a spiral pattern from the helicopter's downdraft. The crate sat exactly where the men had left it, against the tree line on the far side. I approached cautiously, scanning the area for any signs of recent activity. Nothing seemed disturbed. The crate was larger than I'd estimated from the tower, about the size of a refrigerator, made of rough wooden planks with metal reinforcements at the corners. I circled it slowly, looking for shipping labels or any indication of its contents or origin. The wood was unmarked except for one side, which bore a simple black circle logo, perfectly round, and about the size of my palm. No text, no numbers, just a solid black disc painted directly onto the wood. I ran my fingers over it. The paint felt thick and slightly textured. I noticed that the lid of the crate wasn't fully secured. The top panel had been nailed down, but one corner was loose, with enough space to lift it slightly. I hesitated, remembering Leo's instruction to focus solely on fire detection duties, but curiosity won out. I wedged my fingers under the loose corner and pulled upward. The wood creaked as I lifted the lid enough to peer inside. The crate contained what looked like fine black powder, similar to ash, but darker and more uniform in texture. I reached in and touched it gingerly with my index finger. The substance felt waxy and strangely cold, not at all what I expected. When I pulled my hand back, the powder clung to my fingertip in a way that seemed almost deliberate, as if it were adhering to my skin rather than simply sticking to it. I tried to brush it off, but it remained stubbornly attached. I spit on my finger and rubbed it against my pants, but the black substance only smeared, leaving dark stains on both my skin and my khakis. I took out my water bottle and poured some over my hand, rubbing vigorously, but the stain merely lightened slightly without disappearing completely. The whole thing felt wrong. Why would anyone airlift a crate of strange black powder into a national forest and just leave it there? I carefully lowered the lid back into place and stepped away from the crate, still trying to clean my fingers. The sun had nearly set by then, and the clearing was bathed in the fading orange light of dusk. I needed to get back to the tower before full darkness set in. As I turned to leave, I noticed something odd about the grass near the crate. It seemed darker, as if the black powder had somehow leaked out and stained the ground beneath it. But when I looked closer, I saw that it wasn't a stain at all. The grass itself appeared to be dying, turning black from the tips down toward the roots. I hurried back along the trail, occasionally checking my fingers in the fading light. The black stain remained, a stark contrast against my skin. Back at the tower, I climbed the stairs and immediately went to the small sink in the kitchenette. I scrubbed my hands with soap and hot water for several minutes, but the stains on my fingers remained, though somewhat faded. Whatever this substance was, it had properties beyond ordinary powder or ash. I sat at my desk and picked up the radio handset. It was after 9:00 now, but I needed to report what I'd found. "Base, this is Tower 47. Come in. Over." After a moment of static, Leo's voice came through sounding irritated. "This is Base. Harris, you already made your evening report. What is it now? Over." "Sir, I investigated that crate that was delivered by helicopter yesterday. It contained some kind of black powder substance that sticks to skin and doesn't wash off easily. No identifying marks except a black circle logo. Over." There was a long pause before Leo responded, his voice now sharp and cold. "You were instructed to remain at your post and focus on fire detection."You have no authorization to investigate anything in that forest beyond your assigned duties. Leave the crate alone and mind your own business. Is that clear? Over." His tone took me by surprise. "Yes, sir. But shouldn't we report this to..." "That's enough, Harris," Leo cut me off. "Return to your assigned duties. Base out." The radio went silent. I sat back in my chair staring at the black stains on my fingers. Leo's reaction seemed excessive, almost as if he already knew about the crate and didn't want me involved. I completed my regular evening scan of the horizon, noting nothing unusual in my log book, then tried to distract myself by reading one of the paperbacks I'd brought along, but concentration was impossible. Every few minutes, I found myself looking at my stained fingers or glancing out the windows into the darkness beyond. Around midnight, I was sitting at my desk reviewing weather data when I first heard it, a sound like whispers coming from somewhere in the forest below. I stepped out onto the observation deck and listened intently. The whispers seemed to be coming from multiple directions, too distant to make out any words, but definitely human voices. I grabbed my flashlight and swept its beam across the tree line, but saw nothing unusual. The whispering continued, sometimes fading almost to nothing, then growing slightly louder as if people were moving through the forest, carrying on hushed conversations. A twig snapped loudly somewhere to the east, followed by the unmistakable sound of leaves rustling under footsteps. I aimed my flashlight directly toward the sound. The moment the light hit that area, everything went completely silent. I held my breath and listened, but heard nothing more for several long seconds. Then the whispers began again, this time from the opposite direction. I swung my flashlight around quickly, and once again, the sounds stopped the instant the light reached them. This pattern continued for over an hour. Whispers, movement sounds, silence when illuminated, then new sounds from a different direction. I couldn't see anyone or anything moving in the forest, yet the sounds were unmistakable. Eventually, I retreated inside the cabin and locked the door, something I hadn't felt the need to do until now. I sat on my cot with the flashlight in my hand, listening to the occasional whispers that still managed to penetrate the closed windows. A growing uneasiness settled over me. Was I becoming paranoid from the isolation? Four days alone in a tower might be affecting my mind more than I'd anticipated, but the black stains on my fingers were real enough, tangible evidence that I'd encountered something unusual. I stared at my hands in the dim light of the cabin. What was happening in this forest? The strange hikers who appeared in the middle of the night, the mysterious crate with its black powder, Leo's dismissive attitude, and now these whispers from the darkness. None of it made sense. I lay back on my cot, exhausted but too unsettled to sleep. The rational part of my brain suggested that stress and isolation were causing me to overreact to ordinary forest sounds, but another part of me, a more primitive instinct, insisted that something truly strange was happening in the forest around me. I spotted her through the binoculars just after sunset on my sixth night at the tower, a splash of bright red moving between the dark tree trunks, so out of place it seemed like a hallucination at first. I adjusted the focus, convinced I was seeing things after nearly a week of isolation and strange encounters. But she was real, a woman in a red dress walking through the forest, moving with deliberate steps despite wearing what looked like high heels. The absurdity of it struck me immediately. Who wears heels in a national forest? She wasn't stumbling or struggling with the uneven ground either. She moved with an unsettling precision, weaving between trees and over fallen logs as if the forest floor were a smooth sidewalk. I watched her progress for several minutes as she made her way directly toward the tower, not wandering like someone lost, but moving with purpose, as if she knew exactly where she was going. My pulse quickened. After the strange men in the night, the helicopter dropping that crate with its black powder, and the whispers in the darkness, this felt like part of the same puzzle. I set down the binoculars when she got close enough to see clearly with my naked eye. She stopped at the base of the tower and looked up. Even from 70 feet above, I could make out her features in the fading light. Long, dark hair falling over her shoulders, pale skin that seemed to glow against the red of her dress, and large eyes that reflected nothing. "Hello?" I called down, my voice breaking the evening silence. "Can I help you?" She tilted her head slightly, still looking up at me. "My name is Natalie Sawyer," she said, her voice carrying clearly despite its flat, emotionless tone. "I don't need help." The way she spoke sent a chill through me. No inflection, no natural rise and fall, just words delivered with mechanical precision. "Are you sure? It's getting dark and you're not exactly dressed for hiking," I said, gesturing at her outfit, even though I wasn't sure she could see the movement. "The nearest campground is miles away.""I know where I am," she replied in that same monotone. "I don't need assistance." I hesitated, then asked, "Where did you come from? There aren't any roads nearby." She didn't answer my question. She just stood there, looking up at me with those vacant eyes. "Look, it's not safe to be out in these woods alone at night," I tried again. "I can call someone to help you get back to wherever you're staying." "That won't be necessary," she said. Then without another word, she turned and began walking back the way she'd come, her red dress vivid against the darkening forest. I watched her go, baffled by the encounter. Her heels should have sunk into the soft earth with each step, but she moved as easily as if she were on pavement. I grabbed the binoculars again and tracked her retreating figure until the trees began to swallow her up. The whole thing felt wrong. First, Jacob Franklin with his torn clothes and frightened eyes. Then Dylan Romero following the same path, but going the wrong way. The helicopter with its strange cargo. And now this woman in a cocktail dress wandering through a national forest at night. None of it made sense. I was about to turn away when I heard it, a piercing scream tearing through the quiet forest. It came from the direction Natalie had disappeared. A sound of pure terror that made my skin crawl. I dropped the binoculars onto the desk and grabbed my flashlight. My hand closed around the radio next, clipping it to my belt as I rushed to the stairs. I took them two at a time, nearly losing my footing in my hurry to reach the bottom. The forest had grown darker in the few minutes since Natalie had left. I clicked on my flashlight and swept its beam across the tree line where I'd last seen her. "Natalie," I called out. My voice sounding small against the vastness of the forest. "Natalie, are you okay?" No response came back. Just the normal sounds of the forest at night. The rustle of leaves, the occasional hoot of an owl. I hesitated at the base of the tower, remembering Leo's instructions to focus only on fire detection. But someone might be hurt. I couldn't just ignore a scream like that. I started walking toward where I'd heard the sound, my flashlight beam cutting through the darkness ahead of me. The beam caught on tree trunks, undergrowth, fallen logs, normal forest features that now seemed ominous in the dark. "Natalie," I called again, louder this time. "If you can hear me, say something." I moved deeper into the trees, scanning the ground for any sign of disturbance, broken branches, disturbed earth, anything that might indicate someone had passed through or struggled here. But the forest floor looked untouched. I kept going, sweeping my light back and forth methodically. I should've found something by now, footprints from those high heels at the very least. The ground was soft enough that they should've left clear impressions. But there was nothing. No footprints. No scraps of red fabric caught on branches. No signs of a struggle that might explain that terrified scream. I spent nearly an hour searching in widening circles from where I thought I'd last seen her. I checked behind trees, in small clearings, even called her name until my throat felt raw. But it was as if Natalie Sawyer had simply vanished into thin air. Eventually, I had to admit defeat. I stood in the silent forest, flashlight in hand, completely baffled. I'd seen her clearly. We'd spoken. I'd heard her scream. But now there was absolutely no evidence that she'd ever been here. I made my way back to the tower, my mind racing through possibilities. Could she have been some kind of hallucination? Was I losing my grip after nearly a week of isolation and strange encounters? The black stains on my fingers from the crate's powder caught my eye as I climbed the stairs, a reminder that at least some of what I'd experienced was definitely real. But Natalie Sawyer in her bright red dress and impossible heels walking through the forest and disappearing without a trace, I couldn't make sense of it. The memory of her vacant eyes and emotionless voice stayed with me as I locked the tower door behind me, wondering what the hell was happening in these woods. I spotted him through my binoculars during the evening scan, a man in a dark business suit standing perfectly still among the trees facing the tower. At first, I thought he might be lost like the others, but something about his stillness made my skin crawl. Most people shift their weight, look around, check their phones. This guy did none of that. Just stood there, staring up at my position. I adjusted the focus on my binoculars, trying to make out his features. The fading light made it difficult, but I could see he wore a crisp black suit that looked completely out of place in the wilderness. No hiking boots or outdoor gear. Just formal business attire, as if he'd stepped out of a corporate meeting and materialized in the middle of the forest. "Hello?" I called down from the observation deck, my voice echoing through the trees. "Can I help you?" No response, not even a twitch. I tried again, louder this time. "If you're lost, I can give you directions." The man remained frozen, like a statue someone had placed among the pines. His arms hung at his sides and his face was tilted upward toward the tower.I couldn't make out his expression from this distance, but something about that unnatural stillness sent a chill through me despite the warm evening air. 10 minutes passed, then 20. I kept checking through the binoculars, certain he would eventually move, speak, or acknowledge me somehow. But 30 minutes in, he remained in exactly the same position, not a single adjustment or shift in posture. After 45 minutes of this bizarre standoff, I started to wonder if what I was seeing was even real. Maybe it was a trick of the light or some kind of forest service equipment I was misinterpreting. But each time I checked with the binoculars, he was still there, still staring, still motionless. At the one-hour mark, I'd had enough. The black stains on my fingers from the mysterious crate hadn't faded. The memory of Natalie Sawyer's scream still echoed in my head. The whispers from the forest at night hadn't stopped. And now this, another inexplicable visitor who seemed to be following no rules of normal human behavior. I grabbed my flashlight, slipped it into my pocket, and headed for the spiral staircase. After eight days of weird encounters and growing unease, I was done with watching from a distance. I needed answers. The wooden steps creaked under my boots as I made my way down. With each step, I rehearsed what I would say to the man in the suit. Who are you? What do you want? Why are you standing there staring at my tower? Why is everyone in this forest acting so damn strange? I hit the ground and set off in the direction where I'd spotted him, moving with purpose through the underbrush. The spot wasn't far, maybe 200 yards from the base of the tower through a stand of pine trees. The evening light was fading fast, but I still had enough visibility to make my way without the flashlight. As I approached the location, I slowed my pace, suddenly aware of how vulnerable I was out here alone. What if this guy was dangerous? What if he wasn't alone? I listened carefully, but heard only the usual forest sounds, the rustle of leaves, distant bird calls, the soft whisper of wind through the pines. I reached the exact spot where the man had been standing. Nothing. No one. "Hello?" I called out, turning in a slow circle. "Is anyone here?" Silence answered me. I pulled out my flashlight and clicked it on, sweeping the beam across the ground and surrounding trees. The suited man was gone, completely vanished. I checked behind trees, looked up branches, scanned the perimeter in widening circles. What struck me most was the complete absence of evidence. The forest floor here was soft with a layer of pine needles and loose soil, perfect for capturing footprints, but there were none. No depressions where someone might have stood for an hour. No broken twigs. No disturbed vegetation. Nothing to suggest anyone had been here at all. I knelt down, running my fingers over the ground where he should have left some mark. The earth was undisturbed as if no one had stood in this spot for weeks. "This isn't possible," I muttered to myself, standing up and brushing off my hands.
